div.p: By the will of the late Baron Sir Ferdinand von Mueller, K.C.M.G., Government Botanist of Victoria, it is expressed as his desire that the Clock presented to him by the employés of the Botanic Garden should "be placed as a Gift into the Botanic Museum".

p.style: margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: 0in; text-align: start; hyphenation-ladder-count: no-limit; font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; hyphenate: false; hyphenation-remain-char-count: 2; hyphenation-push-char-count: 2;

div.p:
In compliance with the above instructions the Executors would be glad if you would appoint some one to take delivery of the above-mentioned bequest, which we have no doubt the Department will preserve in sacred memory of the illustrious phytologist of whose name and noble life-work the Museum will always be a memorial.
On 11 January 1897 Topp minuted: 'Inform that Mr Luehmann the Curator of the N. Herbarium — will take delivery. Refer to Mr Luehmann accordingly'. A letter was sent to Potter on 12 January. Luehmann later informed Topp: 'The clock was duly received on the 13th January 1897'. It remains at MEL today.
